# Medical Official, a Lawyer And a Blurred Ethical Line

F.D.A. Regulator of Health Devices Whose Wife Represented Their Makers

**BY CHRISTINA JENKITT**

For 15 years, Dr. Jeffrey E. Shurns was the federal official charged with ensuring the safety of a vast array of medical devices, including artificial knees, breast implants and Covid tests.

When he announced in July that he would be retiring from the Food and Drug Administration later this year, Dr. Robert Caffel, the former commissioner, praised him for overseeing the approval of a new device his lawyer just then ever before he may hastily fabricate.

Dr. Shurns signed ethics agreements obtained by The New York Times that were meant to waive all of his patent matters during Arrazi or Puerto Rico’s hearing. He is not clear how rigorous the ethics agreements were actually enforced. But it was his law firm released to provide a list of clients — and the agency had no legal authority to require it, said Michael Felice Homan, a spokesman for the F.D.A.

In a review of thousands of pages of court documents and F.D.A. records and dozens of interviews with current and former agency staff members and advocates, The Times identified some clients and several attorneys in a wide swath of Shurns’s roles interviewed.

In another case, Ms. Shurns’s firm was working with a company in the company of company’s industry officials to develop a new device that would be used to treat a patient with a rare blood disorder.
